image.altText: Unidentified person walks past a 'voting centre' sign in a street.

props.synopsis: With less than a month to Tasmania's state election, a new poll finds Labor in big trouble, the Liberals' dream of a "stable majority government" increasingly unlikely, and voters turning to Independents and minor parties, writes Lucy MacDonald.

title.children: Dream of stable majority government slipping away as Tasmanian poll signals minority future

image.altText: Hands hold mobile phones with blurred images on the screens.

props.synopsis: Child predators are targeting parents on dating apps, with a survey finding one in eight Australian users have received a request to facilitate child sexual exploitation or abuse.

title.children: Child predators are targeting Australian parents on dating apps, survey finds

image.altText: Split screen image, one side shows a hand holding up five hot chips, the other side shows a yellow statue that resembles chips.

props.synopsis: The 'Welcome Gesture' sculpture, a project to "improve the gateway to the city" of Burnie, will cost $1.25 million — with some saying the planned row of "French fries" will be little more than an advert for the fast food restaurant nearby.

title.children: Burnie locals spitting chips over proposed $1.25 million 'French fry' sculpture

image.altText: A man wearing cap and black Tshirt sits at a table with a small camera on a tripod in front of him

props.synopsis: Young people in Japan are leaving for Australia in droves, as the local economy enters recession and cost of living rises out of step with wages.

title.children: Shoma moved from Japan to Sydney for a working holiday, but instead he found a financial bonanza

image.altText: A composite image of close up shots of Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: As Dunkley voters prepare for a by-election this first electoral contest for the year is likely to help define the strategies both sides of politics adopt as they eye the next election. And the cost of living crisis will be hovering on the sidelines, writes David Speers.

title.children: Pollies are waging a compassion contest over the cost of living. Is anyone buying it?

image.altText: An illustration of a wind farm and a solar farm with an hour glass in the middle.

props.synopsis: New South Wales is regarded as 'the most difficult state' for clean energy developers, according to fresh analysis which found the state is taking roughly 3488 days to rubber stamp a wind farm.

title.children: Australia has six years to clean up its power grid. But in one state, it's taking nearly 10 years to approve a wind farm

image.altText: A black and white photo of a Zip sign in a beautician's window.

props.synopsis: If the directors think the company's prospects are bright, some investors say it’s not fair to clear a lot of small investors from the share register. This is what Zip did and that left some of its smaller investors infuriated.

title.children: Zip's small shareholding sale facility angers investors as directors bought near the bottom of the market and gained while others lost out

image.altText: Ben Yole holds bridle of a horse.

props.synopsis: A leading harness trainer who was the subject of a report into race fixing, team driving and animal welfare concerns will be back racing this weekend, as the governing body that temporarily banned him faces criticism over it how it handled its disciplinary action.

title.children: Harness trainer at centre of racing scandal wasn't afforded 'natural justice' when banned

image.altText: A truck dumping stuff on ground at farm.

props.synopsis: A paper company, salmon farmer and water authority provide their industrial waste to a compost facility. But after a mass fish death event — and fines in court — there are calls for things to change.

title.children: A waste spill into a Tasmanian river killed 100,000 fish. Now the mayor says enough is enough

image.altText: A designed image of fake bags on a plinth.

props.synopsis: It's never been easier to buy convincing fake luxury fashion online. But many buyers would be shocked to learn where their money goes.

title.children: How your fake bag could be financing a dark underworld of international crime

image.altText: A firefighter looking at a bushfire

props.synopsis: Fire authorities are confident no homes were lost overnight to two bushfires burning within containment lines in Victoria's west. Cooler conditions are expected to help fire crews today.

title.children: No property losses overnight as crews keep Victorian bushfires contained

image.altText: The rear of a plane with wheels down about to land on a runway

props.synopsis: As Tasmanians get ready to vote in a state election, experts are predicting a gloomy time ahead for the state, with a shrinking population and economic downturn expected.

title.children: From rags to riches, to rags again — is Tasmania's dream run over?

image.altText: Michelle Heyman of the Matildas celebrates a goal.

props.synopsis: The Matildas are off to the Paris Olympic Games after a huge win over Uzbekistan, defeating them 10-0 in the second leg in Melbourne.

title.children: Matildas qualify for the 2024 Paris Olympics with 10-0 thrashing of Uzbekistan

image.altText: A photo of tree with bouquets of flowers laid underneath in a park.

props.synopsis: There is heightened concern in some parts of the community after the death of a student from a falling tree, but experts say the risks of such incidents are low and people should continue to enjoy parks.

title.children: How safe are our trees? Concerns rise after student killed by falling tree

image.altText: A bald man in a suit with his hands clasped on a desk

props.synopsis: An unnamed former Australian politician, who was successfully cultivated by an international spy ring, once suggested bringing a prime minister's family member into contact with his foreign handlers.

title.children: ASIO reveals plot by retired politician to introduce a prime minister's family member to foreign spies

image.altText: Beau Lamarre in a police uniform

props.synopsis: New South Wales Police Commissioner Karen Webb moves to dismiss alleged murderer Beau Lamarre-Condon from the force, flags investigation of his background and files.

title.children: NSW Police commissioner begins process to dismiss murder-accused officer from the force

image.altText: a man wearing glassed stands next to a flag looking sideways

props.synopsis: The government may have to tweak its proposal for a new legal tribunal, which key crossbenchers say is too soft on politicisation.

title.children: Attorney-General hits Senate roadblock in bid for Administrative Appeals Tribunal reform

image.altText: Christian Horner, a caucasian male with stubble, on an F1 pitwall staring to the side.

props.synopsis: Christian Horner has been cleared by Red Bull of any wrongdoing after an investigation into their team principal over allegations of workplace misconduct made by a female employee.

title.children: Horner cleared by Red Bull after investigation into workplace misconduct

image.altText: Prince Harry with a beard looks down while wearing a dark suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Harry, along with other senior royals, had received full publicly-funded security protection provided by the state before he stepped back from his royal duties and moved to California

title.children: Prince Harry loses challenge over government's decision to remove his police protection

image.altText: Len Green with his head resting in his hand.

props.synopsis: Firefighters kept a fire south of Ballarat within containment lines overnight ahead of cooler conditions on Thursday.

title.children: Fire crews keep bushfires within containment lines in Victoria's west

image.altText: Yulia Navalnaya, a blonde woman, standing at a microphone.

props.synopsis: Ms Navalnaya was speaking to the European Parliament in Strasbourg, 12 days after her husband died suddenly in a Russian penal colony at the age of 47.

title.children: 'Putin killed my husband': Yulia Navalnaya, widow of Alexei Navalny, says late husband's body had been abused

image.altText: a close up shot of a man's face staring to the distance. He has short mousy brown hair and a short beard.

props.synopsis: Text messages reveal a News Corp journalist offered to write an article defending former Northern Territory Police constable Zachary Rolfe two days after he fatally shot dead Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: 'You did nothing wrong': News Corp journalist's texts to Rolfe aired at inquest

image.altText: Caterina Mete shares her pregnancy announcement

props.synopsis: For those who have gone through IVF, are solo mothers, used a donor — or are donor conceived themselves — it was a powerful moment of feeling seen.

title.children: 'I wish I had have known from a young age': Wiggles pregnancy helping to 'normalise' IVF and donor conception

image.altText: A close up of the back of a police officer. The black vest reads: POLICE.

props.synopsis: Police are calling for women with relevant information to come forward after charging a 24-year-old man for allegedly knowingly spreading an STI to multiple women.

title.children: Queensland man charged for allegedly knowingly spreading STI to multiple women

image.altText: A sale sign outside a major retail outlet.

props.synopsis: Consumer prices rose 3.4 per cent over the year to January, steady at the same annual rate of inflation as in December.

title.children: Households warned of 'difficult' year ahead, even as inflation slows to its lowest level since 2021

image.altText: A woman in a blue police shirt stares ahead

props.synopsis: The NSW government supports the state's police commissioner Karen Webb following heavy criticism she has faced over comments she made to the media.

title.children: Police minister says she has 'unequivocal confidence' in NSW commissioner after criticism

image.altText: A child sits behind a box of peanuts.

props.synopsis: An injectable medication can reduce the risk of serious food allergy reactions after just four months of use in some people, according to a new study. But there are a few caveats.

title.children: 'Life-changing' injection for food allergies approved in US, not yet on the cards in Australia

image.altText: Sydney Mardi Gras

props.synopsis: NSW Police officers will march in the Mardi Gras day parade after the board changed their earlier decision asking them not to attend.

title.children: NSW Police officers allowed to march at Sydney Mardi Gras, but not in uniform

image.altText: Sydney couple luke davies and jesse baird were allegedly murdered on Monday February 19

props.synopsis: 2024's Mardi Gras will be remembered as the year of pain. Not for the first time, the spectre of violence hangs over the parade. This time it allegedly comes from a police officer and one of the community's own, writes Jason Om.

title.children: Justice must be served for Luke Davies and Jesse Baird. How NSW Police achieve it will be heavily scrutinised

image.altText: Ukraine Ambassador

props.synopsis: The Ukrainian community has appealed directly to Defence Minister Richard Marles to lead a "whole of government" approach to better coordinate Australia's military and humanitarian aid to the war-torn country.

title.children: Ukraine pleads with Australia to donate 'desperately needed' military equipment

image.altText: A woman in a black outfit walking out of court, showing her middle finger to the camera.

props.synopsis: A 27-year-old woman avoids jail time after pleading guilty in the Perth Magistrates Court to assaulting and choking her seven-month-old baby.

title.children: Woman who sent photos of herself assaulting her baby to child's father avoids jail

image.altText: Police officers stand by police tape

props.synopsis: Police say the victim was shot in the groin on the ninth floor of an office building in Sydney's CBD.

title.children: 79yo man charged with intent to murder, string of weapons offences over Sydney CBD shooting

image.altText: An old black and white group photo with a man in glasses and a woollen jumper spotlighted in red.

props.synopsis: The Victorian Education Department sent unqualified teachers into classrooms in the 1960s and then failed to sack them following reports they were sexually abusing their students, according to recently discovered documents.

title.children: 'An educated man who preyed on his students': Woman sues Victorian government over alleged abuse by high school teacher
